‚úîÔ∏èAllow Medicare to negotiate pri‚Ä¶

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text:
Other provisions eliminate loopholes, promote competition, and fight the exploitation of patients by placing fair checks on insurers, manufacturers, and drug companies. (12/12)

Click here to learn about my plan with @RepSchrader to lower drug costs: https://t.co/oFZXAvnhNj

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: Our bill works to lower prices at the pharmacy counter while preserving America‚Äôs unparalleled medical science ecosystem. We want the talent and know-how that has developed therapies and cures and the amazing COVID-19 vaccines to stay on our shores. (11/12)

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: As price-setting scares off investment, it threatens jobs in American science, especially in my district where the life sciences industry employs about 27k San Diegans. (10/12) https://t.co/MgORPV2BtZ

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: If we signal to investors through price setting that they may not be able to recoup their investment not only for their successes, but also their failures, they‚Äôll invest elsewhere & we may well lose our ability to find cures to the toughest and rarest chronic diseases. (9/12)

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: In 2018 alone, private investment funded $102 billion of US drug development ‚Äì dwarfing the budget of the NIH, and without risk to taxpayers. The cycle of risking private investment in research and development for a return down the line has generated great results. (8/12)

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text:
This bill also protects America's ability to find life-saving cures.

The @USCBO found that, accounting for failures, the cost to bring a drug to market could be as high as $2 billion. That‚Äôs for just one drug or treatment. (7/12) https://t.co/VMl6py73ha

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: The Reduced Costs & Continued Cures Act empowers Medicare to negotiate with manufacturers to bring down the cost of expensive treatments when competition fails (i.e. no generic or biosimilar has been marketed & the initial period of exclusivity has expired for a product). (6/12)

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text:
Our bill further reduces the cost burden on patients by ensuring that cost-sharing at the pharmacy counter is based on the drug's post-discount price rather than the drug's original list price. (5/12)
https://t.co/j9L9oFsQZb

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: We also set a ‚ú®$50 out-of-pocket monthly maximum for insulin‚ú® under Medicare Part D plans. This could mean savings of $100s per month for seniors who rely on insulin to manage their diabetes but struggle to pay the expensive costs each month. (4/12)

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text:
To minimize the impact on seniors with fixed incomes, we've included a 'smoothing' mechanism so that those with expensive annual drug costs can pay their out-of-pocket expenses throughout the year via monthly installments instead of all at once. (3/12) 
https://t.co/YcKySPAE3H

name: Rep. Scott Peters

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: The resolution we are marking up today moves us closer to sufficiently curbing methane emissions. But our work cannot stop here. We must work together to form an ambitious and durable long-term framework.

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: Third, our companies can lead the world in developing tech. to monitor and reduce methane emissions. Small businesses comprise two-thirds of the methane mitigation industry and represent the best of US innovation, creating economic opportunity and tackling global challenges.

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: Second, reducing methane emissions is critical to the economic competitiveness of the U.S. natural gas industry. World markets and domestic politics won't tolerate natural gas as a ‚Äúbridge fuel‚Äù unless the industry can credibly prove that it has fixed its methane challenge.

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: First, controlling methane is the single most important step we can take to combat the #ClimateCrisis. Methane is a super pollutant more than 80 times as potent as CO2, and is responsible for about 25% of the human-made warming we experience today. https://t.co/qyqIaVmyY8

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: 21 reconciliation bills have become law throughout history, most recently when Republican's enacted their antigrowth tax bill in 2017. Both parties have taken advantage of reconciliation over the years, and there's no reason a reconciliation bill cannot be bipartisan.

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text:
‚û°Ô∏èAfter committees report out their pieces, the Budget Committee compiles all the bills into a single package that will be considered by the House & Senate.

‚û°Ô∏èIf the House & Senate adopt different versions, they must resolve any differences before a final bill is sent to @POTUS.

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text:
üëâCommittees develop legislation aligned w/ the reconciliation instructions, though all policy details are left up to committee discretion.

(i.e. I'll join my @EnergyCommerce colleagues tomorrow to markup our section of the COVID-19 reconciliation bill:
https://t.co/SO0wzk3XGc)

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text:
‚úÖThese instructions are sent to committees of jurisdiction and outline (1) the amount of $$$ each committee can earmark for the budgetary changes to be made over a certain time frame, and (2) reporting deadlines.
https://t.co/oilDf5s1X7

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text:
The current reconciliation timeline:
‚úÖCongress creates & passes a budget resolution (a plan agreed upon by the House & Senate) for the upcoming Fiscal Year. The reconciliation process is triggered when specific instructions are included in the resolution.
https://t.co/jlrNrz6TGf

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: Reconciliation is a special process that helps lawmakers change tax and mandatory spending policy. It's a tool often used to expedite time-sensitive legislation: a reconciliation bill only requires a simple majority (50 +1 votes) in the Senate instead of the traditional 60 votes.

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text:
The term 'budget reconciliation' has been used a lot during the last few weeks. But what does it really mean, and how will it help you?

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: (10/12) It would direct agencies to form an action plan to reduce super pollutants, boost standards for global methane emissions, codify methane emission rules for new sources, and regulate emissions if industry efforts don‚Äôt decrease emissions by 40% below 2012 levels.

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: (9/12) While the president has backpedaled on regulatory rules, I have spent years working to curb these kinds of emissions. What first started as the SUPER Act I authored in 2013, has become the bipartisan Super Pollutants Act I introduced last year.  https://t.co/sm6mrId3ny

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: (8/12) This is because methane, a main component in natural gas, is a super pollutant far more potent & harmful than CO2. To take advantage of what natural gas offers, it's vital that commonsense regulations are in place to ensure fugitive natural gas emissions are under control.

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: (7/12) Natural gas presents itself as a ‚Äúbridge fuel‚Äù that could help us move to a more sustainable future. While natural gas burns cleaner than coal, any climate benefits are wasted if more than 3.2% escapes through fugitive emissions. https://t.co/f9yV30rkun

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: (6/12) It‚Äôs also cheap. According to @EIAgov, in June 2008, natural gas hit a high of $12.41 per thousand cubic feet. In just 4 years, natural gas has declined almost 80% and there is nothing stopping it from going lower. https://t.co/zl69i6DiwE

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: (5/12) Natural gas is everywhere. üá∫üá∏ is the world‚Äôs largest producer of natural gas, having produced some 761.1 billion cubic meters in 2017. We're also the world‚Äôs largest consumer of natural gas, w/ a consumption of 767 billion cubic meters in 2017, too. https://t.co/pQPDbSG6Ya

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text:
(4/12) Since coming to office, President Trump has actively worked to dismantle critical supervisory systems, insisting oil & gas companies have their emissions under control. According to this @nytimes piece, however, that is clearly far from the truth.
https://t.co/oI49Pmi7UI

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: (3/12) Aggressively cutting super pollutants now could avoid 1.5 degrees of warming by the end of the century. Other research demonstrates that curbing super pollutants could reduce sea level rise 18% by 2050.

name: Rep. Scott Peters

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: Good cops must call out and root out the bad cops. We saw the police chief in Atlanta listen, the chief in Flint join the march, and other officers take a knee. Chief Nisleit banned chokeholds at SDPD; today the SD Sherriff did, too. We need more of that leadership from within.

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: This kind of reform‚Äìmore transparency & independent oversight‚Äìcan rebuild trust between the community & law enforcement. Citizens should feel confident those in uniform will protect us all equally. Rooting out bad actors will also help the credibility and effectiveness of police.

name: Rep. Scott Peters

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text:
Automatic stabilizers that follow economic cues are the most fiscally responsible, long-term solution to the present economic problems our country is contending. (7/7)

Read the letter, here: https://t.co/h0XPZjxTAW

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: The #coronavirus pandemic has uprooted the lives of many Americans and our country will feel the impacts of the damage for years to come. Nearly all economists agree: Congress needs to go big to save our economy. (6/7)

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text:
During the last recession, Congress had to extend emergency unemployment benefits +10 times. As the weak labor market wore on, it became more difficult for Congress to meet consensus and act. 

We cannot afford to make the same mistake twice. (5/7)

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: Adopting automatic stabilizers would do just that - keep federal funding for crucial programs flowing for the duration of the current financial crisis until an economic trigger signals the additional stimulus is no longer needed and can be shut off. (4/7)

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: We know the optimal recession-fighting tools are existing countercyclical programs, like UI, FMAP, SNAP, etc. To revive our economy, it will be imperative to establish rolling federal aid that enhances these programs, as they become more widely needed in the months ahead. (3/7)

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: With over 20 million American jobs lost last month and unemployment continuing to skyrocket, we will need to face the economic calamity head-on and provide stable, ongoing relief to individuals and families across the country. (2/7)

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: THREAD: This morning, I led six of my colleagues in a letter to the Speaker, emphasizing automatic stabilizers as an essential inclusion to the next #COVID19 response package. (1/7) https://t.co/sE0dcQU40o

tweet_text: It's a solution that would address the current emergency and a concept I believe worthy of broader adoption. Taking small steps to embrace automatic triggers for crucial bipartisan relief programs could allow Congress to better prepare for and mitigate future national calamities.

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: Enacting automatic triggers for #COVID19 assistance programs like #PPP or #directpayments would be a smart, efficient, fail-safe way to ensure those struggling receive the financial support they need in a timely manner without having to wait for additional congressional action.

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text:

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: Instead of relying on Congress to come together and vote on new appropriations, automatic stabilizers would keep government assistance rolling by tying the funding for these relief programs to economic or timing triggers.

tweet_text: In our nation's history, thousands have gone into battle to fight for our democracy. In contrast, my Republican colleagues will not speak up for rule of law or against presidential abuse of power. That's the tragedy of today's events. #DefendOurDemocracy https://t.co/GNmQwTn1Bv

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: In contrast, for fear of losing an election, my colleagues will not speak up for rule of law or against presidential abuse of power. Those who don‚Äôt actively excuse the behavior will remain silent and cowardly. Voters may give them a pass, but history will judge them harshly.

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: That‚Äôs the tragedy of today‚Äôs events. In our nation‚Äôs history, thousands of Americans have gone into battle to fight for our democracy. Those young people served without reservation, as they still do today. Many were gravely injured and some made the ultimate sacrifice.

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: Republicans say they want to avoid impeachment, but what choice do they give us? They refuse to seek the truth and condemn the abuse of power to prevent it in the future.

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: I believe the president‚Äôs actions warrant removal from office, but we could have an honest debate. What's not up for debate is what happened, or whether it‚Äôs wrong. It‚Äôs historically criminal and unpatriotic.

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: No House Republican has joined in to demand the documents or witnesses that the president has refused to produce. And Senate Republican leaders have announced that he himself can set the rules of his own trial.

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: Republicans have not sought the truth; they have sought to avoid it. They have demeaned and insulted witnesses‚Äìpatriots, warriors, career diplomats‚Äìwho have provided evidence against the president.

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: Many have lamented that this effort is not bipartisan. That‚Äôs up to my Republican colleagues. I‚Äôve had enough of the ‚Äúboth sides‚Äù rhetoric that characterizes today‚Äôs punditry and journalism. Republicans have excused Trump‚Äôs crimes or pretended they didn‚Äôt happen.

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: The president also obstructed Congress by refusing to allow witnesses to testify. He is not exercising a privilege over particular evidence or testimony. He is just saying Congress can‚Äôt have information. This is unprecedented and a violation of our separation of powers. https://t.co/f75RIdbwHv

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: He pressured Ukraine to interfere in the 2020 elections, just as the Mueller Report showed his campaign cooperated with Russia as it interfered in our 2016 elections. That is an abuse of power‚Äîthe very type our founders referred to when they put impeachment in the Constitution.

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: The facts are not disputed. The president withheld nearly $400 million in foreign aid and a White House meeting from Ukraine in order to force that foreign official to investigate one of the president‚Äôs political rivals. There is no counter-narrative.

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: Today, I will vote to impeach President Donald Trump, consistent with my promise to defend the Constitution from all enemies, foreign and domestic. It‚Äôs now up to the Senate to conduct a trial to decide whether the president should be removed from office.

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: @justinamash And now we are assigned another solemn task by the Constitution and by current events. We need to begin impeachment hearings.

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: @justinamash Democrats are leading on the problems facing Americans: health care, ethics in government, comprehensive immigration reform and border security, gun safety, and civil rights. We must continue to pass groundbreaking legislation, as we have, and as we were elected to do.

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: @justinamash "Our system of checks and balances relies on each branch jealously guarding its powers and upholding its duties under our Constitution. When loyalty to a political party or to an individual trumps loyalty to the Constitution, the Rule of Law‚Äìthe foundation of liberty‚Äìcrumbles.‚Äù

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: @justinamash is right: ‚ÄúThe risk we face in an environment of extreme partisanship is not that Congress will employ [impeachment] as a remedy too often but rather that Congress will employ it so rarely that it cannot deter misconduct..." https://t.co/PkhS2aiBTM

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: If we don‚Äôt act, we send the message that criminal behavior is normal for presidents. Trump will be more emboldened to ignore Congress. And we will increase cynicism among those who depend on us to uphold the law and the Constitution. None of that is acceptable.

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: We should never pursue impeachment for political reasons. Nor should we avoid it for political reasons. It‚Äôs Congress‚Äô job to determine whether the president broke the law and acted against the interests of the United States.

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: Some argue impeachment poses a political risk for Democrats. They say Republicans will claim Trump was vindicated regardless of the outcome. That gives Americans too little credit. I trust them to discern which of us did our patriotic duty and who played to political cynicism.

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: Impeachment is not about the president‚Äôs character or policies. It‚Äôs about upholding the rule of law and defending the Constitution. It‚Äôs about whether he has broken the law. The Mueller Report contains plenty of evidence that he did. Hearings may produce more such evidence.

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: We‚Äôve seen terrible policies from Trump: dangerous foreign policy, tariffs that hurt Americans, reckless tax cuts, cruelty toward asylum-seekers, and attempts to rip health care from millions. I disagree with Trump's policies, but they're for elections, not impeachment.

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: Impeachment is not a redo of the election. Voters accepted a lot that I found appalling: mocking the disabled, childish name calling, attacking war heroes and Gold Star families, insulting Muslims and Mexicans. But while this behavior is abhorrent, it is for voters to judge.

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: The Constitution provides that the president ‚Äúshall be removed from Office, on Impeachment for, and Conviction of, Treason, Bribery, or other high Crimes and Misdemeanors.‚Äù Nobody disputes that felony obstruction of justice is a ‚Äúhigh crime‚Äù under the Constitution.

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: Mueller himself said he did NOT exonerate the president. He felt he could not prosecute Trump because of a DOJ rule against indicting a sitting president. He made it clear it's up to Congress to take further action. Given the record presented, we are duty-bound to proceed.

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: The report also details 10 instances of obstruction of justice by the president, while in office. Over 1,000 former federal prosecutors from both political parties said this evidence is enough to support prosecution and conviction on felony obstruction of justice charges. https://t.co/lWYmYwgllE

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: The Trump campaign was willing and eager to work with a foreign adversary to interfere in our elections. This is far more significant wrongdoing even than the Watergate break-in and its subsequent cover-up which led to Nixon‚Äôs impeachment and resignation.

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: Mueller found a ton of corruption: 34 guilty pleas or indictments of individuals and companies. Five of Trump‚Äôs highest-level associates pleaded guilty to serious felonies, including his campaign chairman, personal lawyer, and national security advisor.

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: My colleagues and I have supported the work of Special Counsel Mueller‚Äôs examination of Russian interference in our elections. I withheld comment on impeachment out of deference to Mueller‚Äôs work and his professionalism. But now we have the report, and it‚Äôs shocking.

name: Rep. Scott Peters
tweet_text: The right to vote is an essential part of our democracy. Sadly, the #ShelbyVHolder Supreme Court decision weakened voter protections from discrimination, intimidation, and disenfranchisement. We must #RestoretheVote to ensure every American has equal access to the ballot box.
